prior_works.title: An Analog of the Minimax Theorem for Vector Payoffs
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s core idea—casting regret minimization on the sequence-form polytope as a Blackwell approachability problem—directly builds on Blackwell’s vector-payoff approachability framework, extending it from the simplex to treeplex/sequence-form domains.

prior_works.title: Efficient Computation of Behavior Strategies
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By operating on the sequence-form polytope, the authors leverage von Stengel’s sequence-form representation as the geometric substrate on which they design approachability and regret updates in extensive-form games.

prior_works.title: A Simple Adaptive Procedure Leading to Correlated Equilibrium
prior_works.role: Regret Matching via approachability; stepsize-invariance on the simplex
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The stepsize-invariant nature of Regret Matching (derived via Blackwell approachability of the negative orthant) is the blueprint the authors generalize from the simplex to treeplexes, yielding Blackwell-style stepsize-invariant regret minimization in sequence form.

prior_works.title: Regret Minimization in Games with Incomplete Information
prior_works.authors: Martin Zinkevich, Michael Johanson, Michael Bowling, Carmelo Piccione
prior_works.role: CFR and self-play for EFG equilibrium computation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Their self-play reduction from regret minimization to Nash equilibrium computation in EFGs is the procedural foundation; the new treeplex Blackwell framework drops in as the regret minimizer within this CFR-style self-play template.

prior_works.title: Smoothing Techniques for Computing Nash Equilibria of Sequential Games
prior_works.authors: Sanjeeb Dash (Sanjeev) Hoda, Andrew Gilpin, Javier Peña, Tuomas Sandholm
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The treeplex structure and associated geometry from this work enable mirror-style updates on sequence-form polytopes; the new approachability-based algorithms exploit this structure to implement efficient regret/approachability oracles on treeplexes.

prior_works.title: CFR+: Faster and Simpler Solving of Imperfect-Information Games
prior_works.role: Regret Matching+ and stepsize-invariant updates in practice
prior_works.relationship_sentence: RM+’s positive-regret, stepsize-free update motivates the paper’s ‘Blackwell+’ perspective on treeplexes; the proposed PTB+ mirrors RM+’s invariance while operating over sequence-form via approachability.

prior_works.title: Online Saddle Point Problems and First-Order Methods
prior_works.role: Predictive/optimistic online mirror descent for games
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s Predictive Treeplex Blackwell+ (PTB+) and its stabilized variant draw on optimistic/predictive OMD to attain O(1/√T) and, with stabilization, O(1/T) convergence in self-play, directly applying the optimistic first-order paradigm to EFGs.

synthesis_narrative: This work fuses approachability theory with the geometry of extensive-form games to produce a stepsize-invariant regret-minimization framework on treeplexes. Blackwell’s 1956 approachability provides the conceptual core: casting no-regret learning as the approachability of a convex set (often a cone). Hart and Mas-Colell’s Regret Matching, itself analyzable via approachability, supplies the model for stepsize-invariant updates on the simplex; the present paper generalizes that invariance to the sequence-form polytope. Von Stengel’s sequence form and the treeplex geometry developed in subsequent work, especially Hoda et al., furnish the representation and distance-generating tools necessary to implement approachability and mirror-style updates over the exponentially structured strategy space of EFGs. The reduction from regret minimization to Nash equilibrium computation in EFGs established by Zinkevich et al. (CFR) is the operational scaffold: the new Blackwell-on-treeplex algorithms plug into self-play to compute equilibria. On the optimization side, the predictive/optimistic online mirror descent framework of Rakhlin and Sridharan underpins the introduction of Predictive Treeplex Blackwell+ (PTB+), delivering O(1/√T) rates in self-play; a stabilized variant achieves state-of-the-art O(1/T), echoing the acceleration seen in optimistic/extragradient methods. Finally, the practical success and stepsize-invariant spirit of RM+ (Tammelin) inform the paper’s plus-style updates in the richer treeplex setting, unifying approachability, regret minimization, and first-order prediction within sequence-form EFGs.
